xxl.core.cursors.groupers

Class HashGrouper<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
      • xxl.core.cursors.groupers.HashGrouper<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by the input iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<Cursor<E>>, Cursor<Cursor<E>>

    public class HashGrouper<E>
extends AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
    A hash grouper partitions input data into groups (strict evaluation). When the hash grouper is initialized a new hash-map is created. The input data is partitioned concerning this hash-map by invoking the user defined, unary function on the given iteration's elements. The hash grouper calls the next method on the input iteration until the hasNext method returns false, i.e., the iteration is completely consumed, so a strict evaluation is performed. Every entry in the hash-map consists of a value and a linked list where the iteration's elements are added to. This means that the hash grouper partitions the data physically. A function is used to compute the hash value of an object. With regard to this value a bucket in the hash-map is assigned, i.e., a new group starts.

    A call to the next method returns a cursor pointing to the next group (the next bucket in the hash-map).

    Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

    Example usage: 

       HashGrouper<Integer> hashGrouper = new HashGrouper<Integer>(
       new xxl.core.cursors.sources.Enumerator(21),
       new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
           public Integer invoke(Integer next) {
               return next % 5;
           }
       }
   );
   
   hashGrouper.open();
   
   while (hashGrouper.hasNext()) {
       Cursor<Integer> bucket = hashGrouper.next();
       // a cursor pointing to next group
       while (bucket.hasNext())
           System.out.print(bucket.next() + "; ");
       System.out.flush();
       System.out.println();
   }
   
   hashGrouper.close();
    This example creates a new hash grouper by applying the function to the objects of an enumerator. So a hash-map is created with the values 0,...,4 and their corresponding buckets. Every entry in this hash-map consists of a value and a linked list (bucket) where the iteration's elements are added to. The implementation of the init method is as follows: 
       HashMap<Object, List<E>> hashMap = new HashMap<Object, List<E>>();
   input.open();
   while (input.hasNext()) {
       E object = input.next();
       Object value = function.invoke(object);
       List<E> list = hashMap.get(value);
       if (list == null)
           hashMap.put(value, list = new LinkedList<E>());
       list.add(object);
   }
   groups = hashMap.values().iterator();
    A collection is returned by applying the method values on the hash map. This collection contains references to all linked lists (buckets) used in the hash-map. The method iterator invoked on this collection returns the elements as an iterator, namely the result-iteration groups.
    In the use case shown above, this iteration is printed to the output stream, i.e., the elements contained in the buckets were printed out. The generated output is as follows: 
         4; 9; 14; 19;
     3; 8; 13; 18;
     2; 7; 12; 17;
     1; 6; 11; 16;
     0; 5; 10; 15; 20;
    The partitions concerning the function (object modulo 5) are represented correctly.
    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, Function, HashMap, NestedLoopsGrouper, SortBasedGrouper

        Parameters:
        iterator - the input iteration delivering the elements to be partitioned.
        function - the unary function returning a (hash-)value for each element.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        protected void init()
        Initializes the hash grouper by creating a new hash-map. Therefore this method partitions the input data concerning this hash-map by invoking the user defined, unary function on the iteration's elements. Every entry in this hash-map consists of a key (hash-value) and a linked list where the iteration's elements are added to.

        The implementation of this method is as follows: 

           HashMap<Object, List<E>> hashMap = new HashMap<Object, List<E>>();
   input.open();
   while (input.hasNext()) {
       E object = input.next();
       Object value = function.invoke(object);
       List<E> list = hashMap.get(value);
       if (list == null)
           hashMap.put(value, list = new LinkedList<E>());
       list.add(object);
   }
   groups = hashMap.values().iterator();
        A collection is returned by applying the method values on the hash-map. This collection contains references to all linked lists (buckets) used in the hash-map. The method iterator invoked on this collection returns the elements as an iterator, namely the result-iteration groups.

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the hash grouper, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources and consume the input iteration to compute its partitions. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the hash grouper, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close the input iteration, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

        Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.) This happens when the result-iteration groups has more elements.
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        true if the hash grouper has more elements, otherwise false.

      • nextObject

        protected Cursor<E> nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration, in this case a cursor. A new iterator cursor is returned by calling the next method on the result-iteration groups.

        More detailed: The next method invoked on the result-iteration groups returns a reference to a list, because the result-iteration consists of references pointing to lists. The method iterator is applied on this list and the returned iterator instance is wrapped to a cursor.

        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the hash grouper to its initial state (optional operation). That means the reset method of the input iteration and the init method of the hash grouper are called. So the caller is able to traverse the partitions again.
        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input iteration.

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the hash grouper. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor<Cursor<E>>
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Cursor<E>>
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the hash grouper, otherwise false.
